questions.explanation:

Calcium Wilson diseases is inherited disorder of copper metabolism , resulting in toxic accumulation of copper in liver leading hepatic disease such as hepatitis, cirrhosis or hepatic decompensation ; brain leading to Parkinsonism like features ; eye leading to Kayser-Fleischer ring. questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with pain in calf for 2 days. 5days ago he had history of fever, sore throat and cough. Currently no abnormality is seen only pain on pressing the muscles. No sensory involvement and has normal DTR's. Investigation revealed a CPK level of 2000 IU/uL. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Viral Myositis Benign acute childhood myositis is a mild and self-limited sudden onset of lower extremity pain during or following recovery from a viral illness. Presentation can include tiptoe gait or refusal to walk, secondary to symmetric bilateral lower extremity pain that resolves quickly, usually within 3 days. An elevated creatine phosphokinase (CPK) level is one of the most common laboratory findings.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy for pituitary tumour now she presented with fatigue and lethargy. Investigations revealed a low ACTH, TSH, FSH and LH. Which of the following hormone need not be given as a part of replacement therapy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mineralocorticoids Aldosterone is the main mineralocorticoid secreted by adrenal gland and is under control of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and it is not under control of pituitary gland whereas the other options in the given question are under control of pituitary. Hence mineralocorticoids need not be given as a part of replacement therapy. Aldosterone levels remain normal as the renin angiotensin aldosterone loop remains intact. Pituitary Apoplexy or Panhypopituitarism A rare but potentially life threatening clinical syndrome resulting from acute haemorrhage or infarction of pituitary gland Clinical features presents with a sudden onset of severe Headache, vomiting, visual disturbances (visual acuity impairment and visual field impairment) and decreased consciousness, Hypoglycaemia, Hypotension, Ophthalmoplegia, Death Occurrence It usually occur in presence of pituitary adenoma most commonly somatotroph or corticotroph adenoma D/D:- post-partum (Sheehan's syndrome), Hypertension, DM, Sickle cell, Acute shock, Carotid angiography, Empty Sella syndrome, Bleeding Disorder, Anticoagulant therapy

Highyeild:

Management consists of careful monitoring of fluid and electrolyte balance coupled with immediate replacement of deficient hormones in particular corticosteroids Surgical decompression may be required in those with progressive neuro ophthalmic signs

Extraedge:

Pituitary Apoplexy Pathophysiology:- Vascularization predominated by direct arterial blood supply ↓ Blood supply reduced compared to normal pituitary ↓ Reduced angiogenesis / fragile blood vessels ↓ Sensitive to glucose deprivation

questions.text: A patient 60years old man presents with CKD develops persistent vomiting and restless in ICU. ABG analysis showed: Na+ = 145, CI- = 100, HCO3- =24, PaC02= 40 and pH = 7.40. What is the most likely metabolic abnormality?

options.label: A

options.label: D
options.text: High Anion gap metabolic acidosis with normal metabolic acidosis.

questions.correct_answer: A. High Anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High Anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis The Anion gap is calculated by = [Na+]- { [Cl-]+[HCO3-] } Here the anion gap in this patient is [145]- { [100]+[24 } = 21mEq/L The normal Anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. The ph is within normal range but the anion gap is increased. This type condition is usually seen in patient with chronic kidney disease and vomiting leads to alkalosis.

questions.text: A 34 year-old male with history of Palpitations came to emergency with a pulse rate 156/min and with a BP- 70/40 mm Hg. Emergency crew has tried vagal maneuver and adenosine to which the rhythm is refractory. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Synchronized Cardioversion T he given ECG shows AVNRT (SVT). ECG findings will show - The QRS duration will be narrow (less than 120 MS) except in cases of PSVT with aberrant conduction (left bundle branch block, right bundle branch block, or bystander accessory pathway). The heart rate is regular and is usually 160–220 beats/min but may be greater than 250 beats/min. The P wave usually differs in contour from sinus beats and is often simultaneous with or just after the QRS complex. TREATMENT - In stable patients - we do carotid sinus massage . It is often performed by clinicians but should be avoided if the patient has a carotid bruit. Firm but gentle pressure and massage are applied first over the right carotid sinus for 10–20 seconds and, if unsuccessful, then over the left carotid sinus. Pressure should not be exerted on both sides at the same time. Medical management - Intravenous adenosine is recommended as the first-line agent. In Unstable patients - it is always synchronized electrical cardioversion (beginning at 100 J) should be performed.

Highyeild:

Rate is 150-300, regular, p often hidden Atia is pacemaker (may got see p waves) reentrant phenomenon Risk factors include:- alcohol, caffeine, nicotine, psychological stress, The underlying mechanism typically involves an accessory pathway that results in re-entry. Diagnosis is typically by an electrocardiogram (ECG) which shows:- Narrow QRS complexes and a fast heart rhythm typically between 150 and 240 beats per minute Vagal maneuvers , such as the Valsalva maneuver, are often used as the initial treatment.

Extraedge:

Causes:- SNS stimulation, MI CH Sepsis

questions.explanation:

Platelet transfusions may be considered for severe thrombocytopenia (less than 10,000/mcL) or when there is evidence of bleeding .

questions.text: The most common pulmonary manifestation of inhalation anthrax?

options.label: D
options.text: Broncho pulmonary pneumonia and respiratory failure

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hemorrhagic mediastinitis Anthrax is a rare but serious illness caused by spore-forming bacteria, Bacillus anthracis. The most serious complication is inflammation of the membranes and fluid covering the brain and spinal cord , leading to massive bleeding hemorrhagic and death. The most common pulmonary manifestation of inhalational anthrax (B. anthrax) is hemorrhagic mediastinitis. Diagnosis: Gram staining Test of infected skin/skin sores Blood testing CT scans and Chest X-Ray Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) Endoscopy of the intestine and throat

Extraedge:

Clinical Features:- Cutaneous (skin) anthrax Cutaneous anthrax is typically caused when Bacillus anthracis spores enter through cuts on the skin . This form accounts for over 95% of anthrax cases. Lesions usually occur on exposed skin and often commence with itchiness. They pass through several stages: papular stage vesicular stage with a blister that often becomes hemorrhagic eschar stage that appears two to six days after the hemorrhagic vesicle dries to become a depressed black scab ( malignant pustule ) which may have surrounding redness and extensive edema (swelling). Anthrax lesions are usually painless but pain may result due to surrounding edema. Inhalational (Pulmonary) anthrax also known as Woodsorter's disease results from breathing anthrax spores into the lungs. Earliest symptoms resemble those of a respiratory infection such as mild fever and sore throat. After one to three days of acute phase, increasing fever, dyspnea , stridor , hypoxia , and hypertension occur usually leading to death within 24 hours. Gastrointestinal Anthrax results from ingestion of inadequately-cooked meat from animals with anthrax. symptoms include fever, nausea, and vomiting, loss of appetite, abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and sometimes rapidly developing ascites . After the bacterium invades the bowel system , it spreads through the bloodstream throughout the body , making even more toxins on the way. This form of anthrax is the rarest .

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection after a post-solid organ transplantation in an Indian setting?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CMV Immunosuppressive drug therapy after transplant is the major cause of immunocompromised status and occurrence of opportunistic infections Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common viral infection, occurring most commonly between post transplant months 1 and 3. CMV is a herpes virus CMV is most common viral infection in solid organ transplantation Non cytomegalovirus virus infections includes varicella zoster viruses, parvovirus B-19, polyomavirus, nocardia mucormycosis.

Highyeild:

Cytomegalic Inclusion Disease CNS abnormalities microcephaly, mental retardation, spasticity, epilepsy, periventricular calcification. Eye - chorioretinitis and optic atrophy Ear - sensorineural deafness Liver - hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice which is due to hepatitis. Lung - pneumonitis Heart - myocarditis Thrombocytopenic purpura, Haemolytic anaemia Late sequelae in individuals asymptomatic at birth - hearing defects and reduced intelligence

Extraedge:

Laboratory Diagnosis Virus Isolation Conventional cell culture is regarded as the gold standard but requires up to 4 weeks for results. More useful are rapid culture methods such as the DEAFF test which can provide a result in 24-48 hours Serology The presence of CMV 1gG antibody indicates past infection. The detection of IgM is indicative of primary infection although it may also be found in mmunocompromised patients with reactivation. Anti-CMV agents in current use are ganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir.

questions.text: What is the best nutritional regimen for end stage CKD patients:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High calorie, low volume High volume is not given as the patient is in end stage CKD, patients tend to retain fluid and would lead to over load of fluids, hyperkalemia, hypophosphatemia & accumulation of toxic metabolites. A high calorie feed is preferred as risk of malnutrition and wasting is seen in CKD. To best assess nutritional status, the serum albumin concentration and body weight should be measured serially; these should be measured approximately every one to three months for those with eGFRs <20 mL/min/1.73 m2 Among CKD patients, overnutrition results in sodium and volume overload, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and accumulation of toxic metabolites of protein degradation. Undernutrition, on the other hand, exacerbates the risk for malnutrition and wasting.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of deafness and recurrent hematuria present with CKD. Family history revealed the death of his maternal uncle due to the same disease. Kidney biopsy was performed and showed a normal light microscopy. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alport's syndrome Alport syndrome is a primary basement membrane disorder arising from mutations in genes encoding several members of the collagen IV protein family, patients with Alport’s syndrome develop hematuria, thinning and splitting of the GBMs, and mild proteinuria (<1–2 g/24 h), which appears late in the course, followed by chronic glomerulosclerosis leading to renal failure in association with sensorineural deafness. Some patients develop lenticonus of the anterior lens capsule, “dot and fleck” retinopathy, and rarely, leiomyomatosis. Approximately 85% of patients with Alport’s syndrome have an X-linked inheritance of mutations in the α5(IV) collagen chain on chromosome X. 85% of patients with Alport’s syndrome have an X-linked inheritance of mutations in the α5(IV) collagen chain on chromosome Xq22–24. Fifteen percent of patients have autosomal recessive disease of the α3(IV) or α4(IV) chains on chromosome 2q35–37. Rarely, some kindred have an autosomal dominant inheritance of dominant-negative mutations in α3(IV) or α4(IV) chains. . All affected members of a family with X-linked Alport’s syndrome should be identified and followed, including mothers of affected males. Primary treatment is control of systemic hypertension and use of ACE inhibitors to slow renal progression.
